BE11:16am

Further assessment of the reasons for the fire at CFC 3 has since been undertaken by the Company, its
insurers, FM Global, and the Hampshire Fire Service. The conclusion reached is that the cause of the fire at
CFC 3 was an electrical fault at one of the first generation battery charging units at the edge of the ambient
storage grid which caused the plastic lid on the top of a grocery carrying robot (a “bot”) to catch alight.
The Company has therefore undertaken a number of remedial actions intended to eliminate the risk of
such an event occurring again which have included the introduction of additional localised smoke
detectors and the removal of the plastic lid on its bots. This lid serves no practical purpose and its
removal has not impacted the efficiency of the bots in any way. The Company also intends to add heat
sensors in the ambient product storage grid which are in addition to the existing sensors in the chilled
storage grid. In addition, the first generation battery charging units were used only at CFC 3 and not in
any other CFC.

BE11:17am

That's the upshot. A bin lid caught fire.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Exclusive image of the CFC robot involved:

BE11:17am

Are we there yet a bin lid burnt a factory down?
Mouselet "the lid serves no practical purpose" is always a reassuring thing to hear from what was presumably a quite carefully engineered object
BE11:17am

All of which is fascinating, of course.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Though perhaps more fascinating is the terms of the M&S JV.

Mouselet a thing which was on fire burned an unoccupied factory down; this is not terribly unusual
BE11:18am

Also buried within the circular. Page 9.

BE11:18am

The entire issued share capital of Ocado Retail is currently held by OHL. Under the Share Purchase
Agreement, OHL will, subject to the satisfaction of the Conditions, sell 50 per cent. of its shares in
Ocado Retail to M&S Holdings for an initial consideration amount of £562.5 million in cash on
Completion. Certain deferred consideration amounts will be paid at later dates if the deferred
consideration trigger events occur, giving a total consideration amount of £750 million in cash. The
aggregate amount of deferred consideration of £187.5 million (plus interest) is allocated across three
different deferred consideration triggers and, in each case, is required to be paid after the occurrence
of each such trigger – together with an amount of interest calculated on a daily basis at the rate of
4 per cent. per annum and compounded annually from Completion to the date of payment – as follows:
• £15.625 million, if, on or before 30 November 2023, the capacity utilised in the Erith CFC
meets an agreed threshold for a continuous period of three months;
9
• £15.625 million, if and when the first delivery to a customer is made from the next CFC to be
established for use by the Company (excluding any facilities developed as replacements for
the Andover CFC); and
• £156.25 million, if Ocado Retail’s adjusted EBITDA for the 12 months ending on the closest
Sunday to 30 November 2023, as adjusted by adding to that amount certain fees paid by
Ocado Retail, reaches or exceeds an agreed amount which is 80 per cent. of the amount
Ocado Retail is currently forecasting for that period.
Both the Company and M&S currently expect that the deferred consideration trigger events will occur
including, where applicable, within the required timeframes under the Share Purchase Agreement.

Are we there yet a four day fire?
11:19 am
BE11:19am

The upshot here is that Ocado only gets the bulk of the money in 2023 if the JV reaches 80% of EBITDA.

BE11:20am

Which looks better for M&S than it does for Ocado, you could argue -- or at least it would if Ocado was still in the food delivery business.

It's not though. It's in the spontaneously combusting technology business. It's the Tesla of grocery logistics.

BE11:29am

Launch a buyback of up to 10% of the share count [~$150m] ASAP: we believe this would be an excellent use of cash in terms of positive share price impact, signaling and NPV accretion from buying back stock on a 25% spot FCF yield (2019E post the recent capex guidance upgrade) vs. virtually any other alternative use of cash. The RNS states this morning the business continues to generate “near-record EBITDA margins and strong cash generation”.

BE11:29am

Which, okay. But does Kostyantin Zhevago tender his shares or not?

11:29 am
BE11:30am

I mean, neither answer seems good.

On the one hand he'd be majority shareholder using company capital to sell down.

wayneJ Haven't the chair of Audit and the chair of remcom also resigned at Ferrexpo?

11:31 am

wayneJ Is this like corporate governance bingo?
BE11:32am

Conclude the forensic investigation as soon as possible: whether BDO can discover more in 3-6 months than Deloitte did in 12-18 months is debatable in our view. As such we would be surprised if BDO were able to reach any different conclusion i.e. that there is a mosaic of evidence to suggest BL may be compromised but no definitive evidence of malfeasance, as noted in Deloitte’s qualification statement and this morning’s RNS (“there are indications that some funds could have been misappropriated”). This would confirm the board was correct to stop payments. Longer-term this issue highlights the governance risk associated with having the majority shareholder as CEO.

VV75 @Blank, well I like this little hour, so it's not gonna be me that is the problem
11:31 am
BE11:32am

Appointment of credible auditor ASAP: the appointment of a respected international auditor appropriate to a FTSE 350 company is key to restoring investor confidence, in our view. With payments to BL having ceased and a comprehensive audit with the FY18 numbers completed, hopefully it means the key area of audit controversy is out of the way.

BE11:32am

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Re-establish balance of independent NEDs: while this is probably easier said than done right now, there is a price for everything and it is a requirement of the premium listing to have a majority of independent NEDs. The board currently comprises one independent NED (Vitalii Lisovenko) and the chairman (Steve Lucas); one non-independent NED (Lucio Genovese, a former PLC director and ongoing director of the Ferrexpo AG subsidiary), the CEO and CFO.

BE11:33am

They're buyers.

BE11:34am

Ultimately we think the main point is that Ferrexpo ceased contributions to BL in May 2018, the amounts involved are negligible ($10m donated in 1H18) and the go-forward cash impact on the business and hence valuation impact is zero. The principal change will be in the discount rate the market puts on the business to reflect Ukrainian country/corruption risk. Given the fall in share price, resulting valuation (25% spot 2019E FCF yield, 2x EV/EBITDA) and catalysts for returning the rating close to prior levels at a time when pellet markets are experiencing their most buoyant conditions in 10 years, we remain Overweight.

the UK, is mature, while

relatively small, leaving the

growth. We think consensus

The acquisition of UK trades directory Checkatrade could also lift profit growth in time, although we think the business is less operationally geared than tech-focused peers. We find a number of potential issues related to HomeServe’s intangibles, which we think distort profitability, returns and cash flow. With valuation at alltime highs, we think the risk-reward is now skewed to the downside and downgrade from Hold to Reduce.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

Which is 50% goodwill, nearly 25% acquired and another 20% for software.

BE11:42am

Why? Here's why.

BE11:42am

Partner payments: in international markets, where its marketing infrastructure is less
developed than the UK, HomeServe effectively buys each new customer from its local utility
partners under long-term marketing agreements. These payments are capitalised and
amortised over the life of the agreement (up to 20 years) through operating costs.
Historically, this model has proved an effective, capital-light means of building scale.
 Inorganic looks a lot like organic: HomeServe regularly buys existing customer books
from future utility partners. Apart from the maturity of the customers, these arrangements
are not easily distinguishable from ‘organic’ agreements (which are also amortised over the
life of the marketing contract). The amortisation and capex costs are, however, treated as
non-operating M&A items and stripped out of adjusted earnings and free cash flow.

BE11:58am

What does it mean for the direct peers? Here's Credit Suisse.

BE11:58am

In itself we do not regard Amazon’s announcement of Prime moving to
standard next day delivery as being an incremental threat to Asos,
Zalando and Next Directory, given that Prime already operates on next day
delivery across most of Europe. Asos Premier offers unlimited next day
delivery for £9.95 pa/€15, and is speeding up delivery times in Europe and US
as it ramps up new DC’s. Zalando is working towards free next day delivery as
standard, and Next Directory offers next day as standard in the UK (Free to
store/Unlimited £20 pa). Moreover for now we do not regard Amazon as a
significant like for like competitor in apparel in Europe at present given the lack
of range and search. We believe the bulk of its apparel sales in Europe are in
basics and low ASP product.
However we do regard it as a negative in the sense that Amazon does set
the tone of customer expectations around fulfilment, and we were seeing an
environment in Europe where online retailers and some multi-channel retailers
were just starting to balance profit protection and sales growth, with higher
minimum order values for free shipping and the start of some customer
segmentation.

wayneJ @Flaneur - I believe that there has been various resets or lack of so rates do not directly reflect rental values. In addition the issue is rates for shops vs eg warehouses ie relative pricing. Thirdly councils have been squeezed by Central govt which increases their duties but cuts their funding.

We've talked often here about the deliveries/returns arms race.

BE12:02pm

Next has performed well (+35%, vs All Share +11%) since the start of the year.
We now see the shares at fair value and are downgrading to Hold. While Next
is well managed compared to many of its peers, we believe the current P/E of
13x adequately reflects EPS growth expectations of c.3-4% alongside strong cash
generation. Our Target Price is maintained at 5600p.

Tax Realist ASOS has changed its return policy recently and "We also need to make sure our returns remain sustainable for us and for the environment, so if we notice an unusual pattern, we might investigate and take action." end of order 10 dresses and send 9 back days are coming.
BE12:03pm

Next Retail profits slide highlights sector challenges: We reviewed the model
alongside this ratings change (albeit leaving estimates broadly unchanged - £712m
moves to £710m PBT). Among Next's detailed FY20 guidance, it's remarkable that the
group anticipates a Retail EBIT margin of just 7.5%, down from 10.9% in FY19. For such
a well-managed group to be achieving profitability at this level highlights the challenges
facing store-based clothing retailers as online channels gain traction. To quote from the
recent final results "we do not have too much space, we have too much rent, rates and
service charge". Next needs lower occupancy costs to feed through to stabilise profitability
on its 500+ store portfolio.

(HOUSTON, April 29, 2019 PRNewswire -- Anadarko Petroleum Corporation (NYSE: APC) today announced that it intends to resume negotiations with Occidental Petroleum Corporation in response to Occidental's proposal to acquire Anadarko, which was announced by Occidental on April 24, 2019 (the "Occidental Proposal"). As disclosed previously, Anadarko entered into a definitive merger agreement with Chevron Corporation on April 11, 2019 (the "Chevron Merger Agreement").)
